elements.content: Reaction of pyrazine-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic acid with Cu(II) under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions causes in situ decarboxylation of two carboxyl groups to form pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid. Coordination of Cu(II) by this ligand generates linear coordination polymers of catena-[diaqua-(μ-pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylato-N,O,O‘-μ-N‘)copper(II).
elements.clean_text: Reaction of pyrazine-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic acid with Cu(II) under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions causes in situ decarboxylation of two carboxyl groups to form pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid. Coordination of Cu(II) by this ligand generates linear coordination polymers of catena-[diaqua-(μ-pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylato-N,O,O‘-μ-N‘)copper(II).

elements.content: Reaction of pyrazine-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic acid with Cu(II) under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions causes in situ decarboxylation of two carboxyl groups with subsequent generation of linear coordination polymers of catena-[diaqua-(μ-pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylato-N,O,O‘-μ-N‘)copper(II).
elements.clean_text: Reaction of pyrazine-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic acid with Cu(II) under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions causes in situ decarboxylation of two carboxyl groups with subsequent generation of linear coordination polymers of catena-[diaqua-(μ-pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylato-N,O,O‘-μ-N‘)copper(II).

elements.content: Considerable effort has gone into the development of porous crystalline solids that derive their porosity from rigid frameworks of molecules. These materials have channels with adjustable dimensions and structures and exhibit permanent porosity with large void volumes as well as high thermal stability. Consequently, porous crystalline solids hold great promise for sensing and separation of molecules, fabrication of nanoparticles, catalysis, storage and exchange of ions and molecules. We are investigating ligands that contain several 2,6-dicarboxypyridyl groups as molecular building blocks for the design and synthesis of porous solids. We demonstrated recently that the assembly of structures containing multiple molecular components can be achieved in thin molecular films and in crystalline solids via metal−ligand coordination with 2,6-dicarboxypyridine groups. Our goal is to prepare new types of metal−organic frameworks with open structures by reacting these ligands with metal ions to generate rigid one-, two-, and three-dimensional (1-D, 2-D, and 3-D) coordination polymers. Accordingly, we are developing a family of soluble organic ligands substituted with two, three, or four 2,6-dicarboxypyridine units attached covalently to a central core.
elements.clean_text: Considerable effort has gone into the development of porous crystalline solids that derive their porosity from rigid frameworks of molecules. These materials have channels with adjustable dimensions and structures and exhibit permanent porosity with large void volumes as well as high thermal stability. Consequently, porous crystalline solids hold great promise for sensing and separation of molecules, fabrication of nanoparticles, catalysis, storage and exchange of ions and molecules. We are investigating ligands that contain several 2,6-dicarboxypyridyl groups as molecular building blocks for the design and synthesis of porous solids. We demonstrated recently that the assembly of structures containing multiple molecular components can be achieved in thin molecular films and in crystalline solids via metal-ligand coordination with 2,6-dicarboxypyridine groups. Our goal is to prepare new types of metal-organic frameworks with open structures by reacting these ligands with metal ions to generate rigid one-, two-, and three-dimensional (1-D, 2-D, and 3-D) coordination polymers. Accordingly, we are developing a family of soluble organic ligands substituted with two, three, or four 2,6-dicarboxypyridine units attached covalently to a central core.

elements.content: Shown on the left in Figure is a general structure representing several different target ligands that we are investigating for generating 1-D coordination polymers. These compounds are linear ligands that feature two 2,6-dicarboxypyridine groups held in fixed positions by a rigid covalent backbone with the pyridine rings oriented pointing in opposite directions. We have chosen ligands with this arrangement of 2,6-dicarboxypyridine groups to promote divergent linear assembly in the presence of metal ions. Of the ligands we have begun to investigate, pyrazine-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic acid ( i ) has the most compact structure with the least conformational flexibility because both 2,6-dicarboxypyridine groups reside on the same ring. Thus, we expected this ligand to form rodlike coordination polymers with a high degree of rigidity.
elements.clean_text: Shown on the left in Figure  is a general structure representing several different target ligands that we are investigating for generating 1-D coordination polymers. These compounds are linear ligands that feature two 2,6-dicarboxypyridine groups held in fixed positions by a rigid covalent backbone with the pyridine rings oriented pointing in opposite directions. We have chosen ligands with this arrangement of 2,6-dicarboxypyridine groups to promote divergent linear assembly in the presence of metal ions. Of the ligands we have begun to investigate, pyrazine-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic acid ( i ) has the most compact structure with the least conformational flexibility because both 2,6-dicarboxypyridine groups reside on the same ring. Thus, we expected this ligand to form rodlike coordination polymers with a high degree of rigidity.

elements.content: Left:  General structure of rigid, linear ligands that contain two 2,6-dicarboxypyridine groups. Right:  Structure of pyrazine-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic acid ( i ).
elements.clean_text: 1  Left: General structure of rigid, linear ligands that contain two 2,6-dicarboxypyridine groups. Right: Structure of pyrazine-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic acid ( i ).

elements.content: Reaction of pyrazine-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic acid with CuCl2 in a 3:1 ratio under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions at 120 °C in H2O in a sealed glass tube produced rectangular blue crystals in solution after 48 h. Single crystals were removed from solution and examined by X-ray diffraction. As shown in Scheme 1, hydro(solvo)thermal synthesis in the presence of Cu(II) ions unexpectedly caused in situ decarboxylation of ligand i that resulted in formation of a coordination polymer of catena-[diaqua-(μ-pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylato-N,O,O‘-μ-N‘)copper(II), 1, instead of coordination polymer 2. In this reaction, pyrazine-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic acid was converted into pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid by the loss of two carboxyl groups. While decarboxylation of pyrazines is known to occur in the absence of transition metals, to our knowledge, this reaction is the first example in which elimination of two carboxyl groups occurs in the presence of Cu(II) under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions. Several cases of hydro(solvo)thermal decarboxylation of a single carboxyl group from aryl carboxylic acids have been reported to occur in reactions involving Cu(II). For example, benzene-1,2,4-tricarboxylic acid loses one carboxyl group to form benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid during synthesis of a mixed-valence Cu(I)/Cu(II) complex under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions. Hydro(solvo)thermal decarboxylation of pyrazine-2-carboxylic acid also occurs in the presence of Cu(II) to give unsubstituted pyrazine. Notably, decarboxylation did not occur in these two reactions when transition metal ions other than Cu(II) were used. We found that decarboxylation takes place in the absence of Cu(II) when ligand i was placed in water at 120 °C for 12 h in a sealed glass tube. Analysis of the resulting crude solid by 1H and 13NMR revealed that i was absent, and that a mixture of pyrazines substituted with from one to three carboxyl groups formed. These results indicate that simply heating under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions promotes decarboxylation and that Cu(II) does not play a catalytic role. This finding is supported by a recent report of a Cu(II) complex with pyrazines-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic acid that was prepared by slow evaporation at room temperature with no incidence of decarboxylation. Instead, Cu(II) either coordinates selectively to pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid in situ as it forms in solution, or it coordinates to ligand i before decarboxylation occurs and prevents further decarboxylation of pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid by forming 1. Although decarboxylation of carboxylic acids can happen both by homolytic and heterolytic cleavage of the C−C bond by a variety of mechanisms (with a heterolytic pathway occurring most frequently under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions), we have not yet determined the mechanism by which decarboxylation takes place on ligand i .
elements.clean_text: Reaction of pyrazine-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic acid with CuCl2 in a 3:1 ratio under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions at 120 °C in H2O in a sealed glass tube produced rectangular blue crystals in solution after 48 h. Single crystals were removed from solution and examined by X-ray diffraction. As shown in Scheme 1, hydro(solvo)thermal synthesis in the presence of Cu(II) ions unexpectedly caused in situ decarboxylation of ligand  i  that resulted in formation of a coordination polymer of catena-[diaqua-(μ-pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylato-N,O,O‘-μ-N‘)copper(II), 1, instead of coordination polymer 2. In this reaction, pyrazine-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic acid was converted into pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid by the loss of two carboxyl groups. While decarboxylation of pyrazines is known to occur in the absence of transition metals, to our knowledge, this reaction is the first example in which elimination of two carboxyl groups occurs in the presence of Cu(II) under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions. Several cases of hydro(solvo)thermal decarboxylation of a single carboxyl group from aryl carboxylic acids have been reported to occur in reactions involving Cu(II). For example, benzene-1,2,4-tricarboxylic acid loses one carboxyl group to form benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid during synthesis of a mixed-valence Cu(I)/Cu(II) complex under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions. Hydro(solvo)thermal decarboxylation of pyrazine-2-carboxylic acid also occurs in the presence of Cu(II) to give unsubstituted pyrazine. Notably, decarboxylation did not occur in these two reactions when transition metal ions other than Cu(II) were used. We found that decarboxylation takes place in the absence of Cu(II) when ligand  i  was placed in water at 120 °C for 12 h in a sealed glass tube. Analysis of the resulting crude solid by 1H and 13NMR revealed that  i  was absent, and that a mixture of pyrazines substituted with from one to three carboxyl groups formed. These results indicate that simply heating under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions promotes decarboxylation and that Cu(II) does not play a catalytic role. This finding is supported by a recent report of a Cu(II) complex with pyrazines-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic acid that was prepared by slow evaporation at room temperature with no incidence of decarboxylation. Instead, Cu(II) either coordinates selectively to pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid in situ as it forms in solution, or it coordinates to ligand  i  before decarboxylation occurs and prevents further decarboxylation of pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid by forming 1. Although decarboxylation of carboxylic acids can happen both by homolytic and heterolytic cleavage of the C-C bond by a variety of mechanisms (with a heterolytic pathway occurring most frequently under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions), we have not yet determined the mechanism by which decarboxylation takes place on ligand  i .

elements.content: The X-ray crystal structure of 1 shows that two of the carboxylic acid groups ortho to the same ring nitrogen atom on pyrazine-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic acid undergo decarboxylation and are replaced by hydrogen atoms. As shown in Figure , the resulting ligand of pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid forms a coordination polymer with tridentate and monodentate binding of Cu(II) ions at opposite ends of the ligand. Tridentate coordination involves formation of a Cu−N bond to the ring nitrogen and Cu−O bonds to oxygen on both ortho carboxylate groups, while monodentate coordination involves formation of a single Cu−N bond to the remaining ring nitrogen. Two molecules of water also serve as ligands that bind to Cu(II) ions. Shown in Figure is a view of crystal packing viewed down the c-axis. Linear strands of 1 pack in the monoclinic space group P21/c with their long axes aligned along the a-axis. Each strand connects to four nearest neighbors via O−H···O hydrogen bonds between the molecules of water and the carboxylate groups, as shown in Figure . Within a given strand, adjacent pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylate groups assemble head-to-tail with N1 and N4 on adjacent ligands coordinating to the same Cu(II) ion. This acentric arrangement generates a linear polymer with a polar structure. Leciejewicz et al recently reported a coordination polymer featuring a similar head-to-tail arrangement of pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylate groups bound to Zn(II) ions. The Zn(II) complex was prepared using pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid rather than pyrazine-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic acid as the starting material under non-hydro(solvo)thermal conditions. Interestingly, the pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylate ligand in both structures bonds to Cu(II) and Zn(II) ions in a head-to-tail configuration to the exclusion of isomers with other configurations. For example, hypothetical coordination polymer 1‘ (Scheme 1) features a head-to-head configuration that generates a framework with a nonpolar structure. Our previous studies of molecular assembly in crystalline solids and thin films show that a head-to-head configuration is the most common arrangement in complexes that contain 2,6-dicarboxypyridine groups coordinated to divalent first-row transition metals. Although this precedent establishes that the structure of 1‘ is reasonable and even to be expected, 1‘ was not observed. Moreover, the crystal structure of a coordination polymer with the structure of 1‘ has not been reported. Although molecular models indicate that head-to-tail assembly may be less demanding sterically than head-to-head assembly, it is difficult to understand why the structure of 1 is favored without carrying out detailed computational studies of the energetics inherent in the structures of 1 and 1‘. Further examination of the assembly of substituted pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylates with other transition metals is worthwhile to establish whether this acentric head-to-tail motif is a general phenomenon that is useful in the design of crystalline materials. As such, derivatives of 1 should provide a paradigm for crystal engineering of solids that require polar assemblies of molecules (e.g., nonlinear optical materials).

As shown in Figure , the resulting ligand of pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid forms a coordination  polymer with tridentate and monodentate binding of Cu(II) ions at opposite ends of the ligand. Tridentate coordination involves formation of a Cu-N bond to the ring nitrogen and Cu-O bonds to oxygen on both ortho carboxylate groups, while monodentate coordination involves formation of a single Cu-N bond to the remaining ring nitrogen. Two molecules of water also serve as ligands that bind to Cu(II) ions. Shown in Figure  is a view of crystal packing viewed down the c-axis. Linear strands of 1 pack in the monoclinic space group P21/c with their long axes aligned along the a-axis. Each strand connects to four nearest neighbors via O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds between the molecules of water and the carboxylate groups, as shown in Figure . Within a given strand, adjacent pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylate groups assemble head-to-tail with N1 and N4 on adjacent ligands coordinating to the same Cu(II) ion. This acentric arrangement generates a linear polymer with a polar structure. Leciejewicz et al recently reported a coordination polymer featuring a similar head-to-tail arrangement of pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylate groups bound to Zn(II) ions. The Zn(II) complex was prepared using pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid rather than pyrazine-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic acid as the starting material under non-hydro(solvo)thermal conditions. Interestingly, the pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylate ligand in both structures bonds to Cu(II) and Zn(II) ions in a head-to-tail configuration to the exclusion of isomers with other configurations. For example, hypothetical coordination polymer 1‘ (Scheme 1) features a head-to-head configuration that generates a framework with a nonpolar structure. Our previous studies of molecular assembly in crystalline solids and thin films show that a head-to-head configuration is the most common arrangement in complexes that contain 2,6-dicarboxypyridine groups coordinated to divalent first-row transition  metals. Although this precedent establishes that the structure of 1‘ is reasonable and even to be expected, 1‘ was not observed. Moreover, the crystal structure of a coordination polymer with the structure of 1‘ has not been reported. Although molecular models indicate that head-to-tail assembly may be less demanding sterically than head-to-head assembly, it is difficult to understand why the structure of 1 is favored without carrying out detailed computational studies of the energetics inherent in the structures of 1 and 1‘. Further examination of the assembly of substituted pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylates with other transition metals is worthwhile to establish whether this acentric head-to-tail motif is a general phenomenon that is useful in the design of crystalline materials. As such, derivatives of 1 should provide a paradigm for crystal engineering of solids that require polar assemblies of molecules (e.g., nonlinear optical materials).

metadata.title:
Generation of Linear Coordination Polymers of
c
atena-[Diaqua-(μ-pyrazine-2,6-dicarboxylato-N,O,O‘-μ-N‘)copper(II) via in Situ
Hydro(solvo)thermal Decarboxylation of Pyrazine-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic Acid
